>From: "Derek James" <djames@...>

>So it seems to me that you can't logically separate the end result
>from the evolving topologies.  If there's waste at the end, there
>was waste throughout.

Correct me if I am wrong, but it seems to me that if you include a 
complexity penalty in the fitness function, you create an evolutionary 
pressure towards or bias for simpler networks.  This pressure will cause the 
search to favor avenues that end up going directly to the final solution 
without picking up a lot of baggage along the way.  The only exception is 
where it is absolutely necessary to gather in some 'baggage' in order to 
arrive at the final solution, which I can't envision ever actually being 
necessary.  Or in the early phases when no specimen has yet even approached 
a solution.

Also, wouldn't it be true that irrelevant topology would tend to 'remove' 
itself by means of low weights?  Any random mutation that increased the 
weights of irrelevant topology would decrease fitness, right?  So relevant 
'paths' would tend to form a relationship to one another, and irrelevant 
topology would tend to decrease relative to it.  Or is that a 
misunderstanding?  True, that doesn't help you reduce computational costs 
during evolution, which is part of the goal (yes?), but if correct, it would 
help you identify the non-contributing structure.

On the other hand, there is 'irrelevant' and then there is 'excessive.'  For 
example, full interconnection with a large number of hidden nodes may be 
overkill for a particular problem.  But how would you identify the 
'irrelevant' nodes?  Since each one contributes to the solution (if the 
weights are right), you can't drop any.

-- John
